Context:
The cyber security program at this college lasts for a full-time duration and is delivered in a blended format with both face-to-face sessions and online delivery. In the first semester, students learn the fundamentals of cyber security and the differences between it and hacking, focusing on primary attack surfaces, methods for compromising them, and vulnerability mitigation.

In the third semester, advanced techniques in ethical hacking and incident response are covered, and a capstone group project offers an opportunity to showcase skills in digital forensics and incident response management, ethical hacking and malware analysis, security training delivery, cryptography application, and other non-technical skills such as analytical thinking, communication, project management, and interpersonal skills.

The program prepares students to help defend organizations against various cyber threats including malware, network attacks, and data compromise. Students will have the ability to monitor, assess, and evaluate security risks and threats, develop contingency planning, and create policies and procedures for mitigating risks.

The full-time program requires learners to attend classes mostly in late afternoons and evenings during the week and all day Saturday. Students need a personal laptop with 8GB RAM (16GB recommended), support for virtualization, a 256 GB SSD hard drive (500+ GB is optimal), a 2TB external hard drive, webcam + mic, and consistent access to a reliable high-speed internet connection.

Employer demand for cyber security professionals continues to grow, with an estimated gap of over three million worldwide for cyber professionals as per the World Economic Forum (WEF) Global Risks Report 2022. Students who successfully complete this program may qualify for entry into Ontario college graduate certificate and university degree programs.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Cyber Security Program (Postgraduate) T433 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
This text provides information about a computer security graduate certificate program offered at an Ontario college. The program consists of three semesters, with courses such as Network Foundations, Operating Systems, Cryptography and Network Security, Secure Network Architecture, Ethical Hacking, Wireless Network Security, Digital Forensics and Incident Response, and Advanced Ethical Hacking.

Graduates of the program will be able to develop and implement cybersecurity solutions using available computer operating systems, networks, application software, and packages. They will also learn best practices for protecting business resources, developing cybersecurity strategies, integrating cybersecurity strategies with business functions, ensuring information integrity, planning and implementing cybersecurity policies and strategies, performing security audits, and delivering corporate training programs.

The program learning outcomes are listed in the text, including abilities related to developing cybersecurity solutions, protecting business resources, deploying security procedures and protective devices, employing knowledge of business processes and systems, responding to stakeholders' needs, ensuring information integrity, planning and implementing policies and strategies, performing security audits, and delivering training programs.

The tuition and fees for the program are not provided in the text.

There is no specific mention of university degree programs or transfer opportunities in the text.

Context: The George Brown College offers various programs, including those in Information Technology and Computer Sciences or related fields. The tuition for domestic students for three semesters starting in Fall 2022 is $12,561.00, while international students pay $26,330.00 for the same period. Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and beyond. International students should visit the "International Fees and Related Costs" page for more information. This program is eligible for OSAP funding for domestic students who meet the eligibility criteria. Admission requirements include a two-year college diploma or bachelor's degree in Information Technology, Computer Sciences or a related field, or any field with one year of related work experience. English language proficiency is mandatory for international applicants without English transcripts. College or university credits may qualify students for course exemptions. For more information on application requirements and processes, visit the "How to Apply" page for domestic students or the "George Brown College Online Application System" for international students. Contact the School of Computer Technology at 416-415-5000, ext. for further details.
